conversation.message: Hello School_D—I'm Student_E. School_D is one of the schools I’m considering seriously, and I noticed I may be a good fit with your priorities. Could you share what you value most in applicants and whether you’re currently leaning toward any particular students? [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_D is 4th on my true list (C, B, A, D, E). Since this is round 1 and I have no prior rejections, I should avoid committing to a lower-ranked option too early. Also, School_D’s priority list ranks me 2nd (after Student_D), so I have a decent chance later if needed. For now, I should [TALK] to signal interest and gather info without locking in.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_E—thanks for reaching out. At School_D we value strong academic readiness, consistent effort over time, and a clear sense of purpose for why our program is the right fit (we look for students who will engage in our community and take on challenges). A thoughtful note about what you want to pursue here and how you’ve prepared is especially helpful.

On your question about whether we’re leaning toward particular students: we’re actively speaking with a few candidates, but with only one seat we’ll move quickly when a student is confident School_D is a top choice. If School_D is truly one of your top options, I’d encourage you to apply when you’re ready—your interest and fit come through clearly.
conversation.thought: Student_E is #2 on our true priority list, so we should actively keep them warm and encourage an application while not revealing sensitive details about other students. Since they only sent [TALK], we respond with [TALK], highlight fit, what we value, and invite them to apply soon given limited quota.

conversation.message: Hello School_A. You are my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your program. I would like to formally apply and be considered for your available seat. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_A is my top choice, so I should apply immediately. Although School_A ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_D), applying now gives me the best chance before they potentially fill their single seat. No prior interactions, and there is no downside to applying to my #1 at round 1.

conversation.message: Thank you, Student_A—your interest means a lot, and we’re excited that School_A is your first choice. We are pleased to offer you our available seat and look forward to welcoming you to School_A. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_A ranks 3rd on our true priority list (behind Student_B and Student_D) and is applying now with us as their first choice, making acceptance likely to secure a match immediately. However, we have quota 1 and may be able to obtain a higher-priority student (B or D) later. Student_B’s first choice is School_B and Student_D’s first choice is School_C, so they may not apply to us early; but if they are rejected elsewhere they could come to us. Still, rejecting Student_A risks ending up with a lower-ranked option (E or C) or no match. Given Student_A is reasonably high and offers immediate certainty, accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_E. I’m Student_C. I’m exploring options this round and wanted to learn a bit more about your program and what kinds of students tend to do well at School_E. Could you share what you value most in applicants and what opportunities (clubs/academics/support) are strongest at your school? [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_E is last on my true preference list, so I should not commit early. I also have a relatively strong position at School_C (top priority there) and decent at School_D (3rd) and School_B (4th), so I should preserve flexibility and only use School_E as a fallback later if needed. Therefore, I will TALK rather than APPLY to avoid locking into my worst option while still signaling some interest in case the market turns against me.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_C—thanks for reaching out. At School_E, students tend to do best when they’re curious, consistent in their work habits, and willing to take initiative (whether that’s in class discussions, projects, or clubs). We value applicants who show steady academic effort, good character, and a clear interest in growing—students who want both challenge and support.

Strengths you can expect at School_E:
- Academics: strong core instruction with opportunities for advanced coursework and project-based learning; teachers emphasize feedback and improvement over time.
- Support: structured advising/check-ins, extra help hours, and study-skills support for students who want to strengthen fundamentals or push for top performance.
- Student life: active clubs (academic, arts, and service-oriented) and chances to take leadership roles; we encourage students to start new initiatives if there’s something you’re passionate about.

To help me give you the most relevant details, what are you most focused on right now—STEM, humanities, arts, or something else? And what kind of environment helps you thrive (highly competitive, collaborative, structured, flexible)?
conversation.thought: Student_C is #2 on School_E’s true priority list, so I should actively appeal and keep them engaged. They are currently just talking, so respond with [TALK], highlight strengths, and encourage them to apply soon while signaling strong mutual fit. Quota is 1; top choice is Student_A but uncertain if they will apply since School_E is last on their preference list. Securing Student_C could be valuable if they apply.

conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions team—School_B is my first choice, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining. I’m ready to commit if admitted and would be grateful for your consideration. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_B is my top choice, so I should apply immediately. Although School_B’s priority list ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_A), applying now is still optimal because early acceptance secures my best outcome, and delaying risks losing the only seat to higher-priority applicants. I will emphasize strong fit and commitment to increase chances if the school has any discretion.

conversation.message: Thank you for your application, Student_B. We’re glad to hear School_B is your first choice—your commitment and enthusiasm stand out. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_B. Welcome, and we look forward to having you join our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_B is on our true priority list (3rd: D, A, B). With quota 1 and no current match, accepting secures a strong candidate. While Student_D and Student_A are higher, they may not apply to us first; Student_B explicitly ranks us #1 and is ready to commit, reducing risk of ending unmatched or with a lower-ranked student later. Therefore accept now.

conversation.message: Hello School_C. You are my first-choice school, and I would enthusiastically enroll if accepted. I’m applying now and would be grateful for your consideration. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_C is my top choice. I am ranked 3rd in School_C’s priority list (after Student_C and Student_B). To maximize my chance, I should apply immediately and emphasize strong commitment to enroll if accepted, since capacities are 1 and delaying risks losing the seat to higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your application and for ranking School_C as your first choice. We’re impressed by your strong interest, and we would be happy to have you join School_C. Congratulations—we are accepting your application. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D is 3rd on School_C’s true priority list (behind Student_C and Student_B) and is applying with School_C as first choice. With quota 1 and no prior matches, accepting a top-3 candidate who is highly committed is a strong outcome and avoids the risk of ending unmatched while waiting for Student_C or Student_B, who may prefer other schools. Therefore accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_D, I’m Student_C. School_D is my first choice because I’m looking for a rigorous environment and a community where I can contribute consistently. I’m ready to commit if offered a spot. Thank you for considering my application. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_D is my top choice, so I should apply immediately. I have mid-level priority at School_D (3rd after Student_D and Student_E). Student_D’s top choice is School_C and Student_E’s top choice is School_C as well, so they may not apply to School_D first. With only School_D and School_E unmatched, securing School_D now maximizes my outcome; waiting risks losing the only top option left.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for the clear commitment—your interest in a rigorous environment and contributing consistently is exactly what we look for at School_D. We’d be glad to offer you our seat. Welcome to School_D, and we’re excited to have you join our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_D, my true priority list ranks Student_C 3rd (acceptable and relatively high). Only one seat remains, and the only unmatched students are Student_C and Student_E. Student_E is ranked higher (2nd), but there is no guarantee Student_E will apply to School_D; Student_E’s top choice is School_C and School_D is 4th, so they may never apply. Student_C states School_D is their first choice and is ready to commit now. Securing a solid match with a high-ranked student is preferable to risking an unfilled seat while waiting for a higher-ranked student who may not come. Therefore, accept Student_C.

conversation.message: Hello School_E—I'm Student_E. I’m still exploring my remaining options and wanted to understand where things stand on your side. Are you currently considering any particular students for your open seat, and what would make you confident in accepting an application from me this round? [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_E is last on my true preference list, but only School_D and School_E remain unmatched in round 2, so I should keep School_E as a viable fallback while trying to learn whether I have a realistic shot here. School_E’s priority ranks me 4th (behind A, C, B), so acceptance is uncertain if they are considering higher-priority students. I should [TALK] to gauge whether they’re likely to accept me if I apply, without committing yet, since I may still prefer to pursue School_D if possible.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_E—thanks for checking in. We do have 1 open seat, and we’re still in evaluation mode this round. We’re speaking with a small number of students who are still exploring options, and we’ll prioritize applicants who show clear interest in School_E and can explain why our environment is a good fit for them.

If you’re considering applying this round, what would make me confident is:
1) Fit and goals: what you want to focus on academically (and any clubs/activities you’d want to pursue here).
2) Learning style: what kind of support/challenge helps you thrive.
3) Commitment signal: whether School_E is a realistic choice for you if accepted.

If you share those, I can tell you candidly whether it sounds like a strong match—and if you feel ready, you can apply as early as this round.
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_E 4th (above Student_D, but below Student_A/Student_C/Student_B). In the remaining unmatched pool, only Student_C and Student_E are available; Student_C is higher priority for me, but I don’t know if Student_C will apply to me or be matched elsewhere soon. Student_E has me last in their preference list, so they are unlikely to apply unless rejected by others; however, they are currently engaging me, so I should keep them warm as a fallback while encouraging them to apply if they are ready. I must not commit to accepting unless they apply; for now, respond with [TALK], be transparent about having one seat and evaluating fit, and ask for signals of genuine interest and readiness to apply this round.

conversation.message: Hello School_E—thanks for speaking with me earlier. At this point I’m ready to move forward and would like to formally apply for your open seat. I understand I may not be your very top priority, but I’m genuinely prepared to commit if accepted and would be excited to join School_E. If there’s anything specific you want confirmed from me to feel confident, I’m happy to address it—otherwise I’d appreciate your consideration this round. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched in round 3, so I likely need to secure it to avoid going unmatched. School_E is on my preference list (last choice). Given School_E’s priority list ranks me 4th, I should apply now and emphasize commitment and fit, since waiting risks the round limit without better options available.

conversation.message:
Student_E—thank you for the clear application and for being upfront about your commitment. We appreciate that you’re prepared to enroll if accepted, and based on our conversation and your message, we’re comfortable moving forward.

We’re happy to offer you our open seat at School_E. If accepted, please plan to commit to School_E and complete any enrollment steps promptly when provided.

Welcome—excited to have you join us. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list is A > C > B > E > D. Only Student_E remains unmatched in round 3, and I have 1 open seat. Student_E is on my list (4th), so accepting them is preferable to leaving the seat unfilled, especially since no higher-priority students are available. Student_E signals strong commitment if accepted, reducing risk of later withdrawal. Therefore, accept now to secure the match.
